content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Jennifer Bennett: I was born in Colorado, in a small mountain town, and I grew up in a close-knit family. My parents were both educated—my father had a graduate degree, and my mother had a bachelor's. We were never short on resources, and I always felt fortunate to have that stability. I remember growing up in a house filled with books and music, and my mother was always encouraging me to pursue my interests. I was a quiet child, more inclined to read than to play outside, which my father found amusing because he was an outdoorsman. I went to college right after high school, though I wasn't sure what I wanted to do. I ended up majoring in English, which was a bit of a surprise to my parents, but they supported me all the way. After college, I met my husband, and we got married in our early 20s. We moved to Boulder a few years later, and I've been living here ever since. I've always been a firm believer in the importance of community and education, which is why I've always leaned toward liberal values and strongly support the Democratic Party.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Jennifer Bennett: Yes, there was a moment that truly shaped the course of my life. I was in my second year of college, majoring in English, and I had this internship opportunity at a local community theater. I was hesitant because I had never acted before, and I didn't see how it would relate to my studies. But my mother, who had always been supportive of my creative side, encouraged me to take it. That summer, I was cast in a small role in a production of *Our Town*. It was terrifying at first, but I found a passion for storytelling that I hadn't realized I had. After that, I started writing my own plays and even helped direct a few student productions. That experience made me realize that I wanted to be involved in the arts in some capacity, even if it wasn't the traditional path I had imagined. It also made me more confident in my voice and more committed to using my education to make a difference in my community. That crossroads led me to where I am today—someone who values creativity, education, and community, and who is deeply committed to the ideals of the Democratic Party.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Jennifer Bennett: I think it was a conscious choice, but one that felt almost inevitable once I experienced it. I had always been the quiet one, the one who preferred books to conversation, but that summer in the theater, something shifted inside me. It wasn't just about acting—it was about connecting with people through stories, and that felt like a purpose. I remember sitting in the audience after my first performance, hearing the applause, and realizing that I had something to offer the world in a way I hadn't before. I made a decision then to follow that path, even if it meant stepping outside of what my parents or even I had expected. I think that moment was the beginning of who I am today—someone who believes in the power of stories to change lives, and who is committed to using that belief to support the values I hold dear.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Jennifer Bennett: Absolutely, I think I was incredibly lucky to have my mother's support during that time. She had always been the one to encourage my creative side, even when I wasn't sure I had one. She didn't push me toward acting or writing, but she made sure I felt safe to explore those interests. Looking back, I think that kind of encouragement is something many people don't get, especially in families where traditional paths are expected. I also had a professor in my English department who took an interest in my work after I started writing plays. He became a mentor of sorts, offering feedback and connecting me with local theater groups. Without those two people—my mother and that professor—I don't think I would have had the confidence to take that first step. It reminds me how important it is for communities to support individuals in finding their own paths, especially when those paths aren't the ones that are most commonly traveled.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Jennifer Bennett: Yes, I have a husband, Mark, and we have two children—Emily, who's 12, and Liam, who's 8. They're both in school here in Boulder, and we live in a cozy home on Aspen Lane. Mark works in renewable energy, which aligns with our shared values around sustainability and social justice. He's very involved in the community, too, volunteering with local environmental groups. Our kids are creative like me, though they have their own passions—Emily loves painting, and Liam is into robotics. It's a busy but fulfilling life. I've always believed that family is the foundation of a strong community, and I try to model that for my children. I want them to grow up understanding the importance of empathy, education, and standing up for what's right—values that have shaped my life and that I hope will shape theirs as well.

Going through the interview questions reminded me of how much my life has been shaped by the people and experiences I've had. From my childhood filled with books and music to the pivotal moment in college when I stepped onto the stage for the first time, each part of my journey has led me to where I am today. It's amazing how one small decision—like taking that theater internship—can change the course of your life in ways you never expected. I'm grateful for the support of my mother and my professor, who helped me find my voice and pursue my passions. Now, as a mother of two children with their own creative interests, I see the same values I grew up with reflected in my family. It's comforting to know that the lessons I've learned about community, education, and the power of stories are ones I can pass on to the next generation.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Jennifer Bennett: My immediate family includes my parents, Robert and Margaret, who still live in the mountain town where I was born. They visit us in Boulder whenever they can, and we always make time for them. My father, Robert, is retired now but was a professor of environmental science before he retired. He's always been passionate about nature and sustainability, which is something Mark and I deeply respect. My mother, Margaret, is still very active in the community—she volunteers at the local library and runs a book club for seniors. Our relationship has always been close, and I think that's why I feel so comfortable being myself around them. They've always supported my choices, even when they didn't fully understand them. I think that kind of unconditional support is rare, and I'm very grateful for it. I also have a younger sister, Sarah, who lives in Denver. She's a nurse, and we keep in touch regularly. She's always been the more outgoing one of us, and I think that's why I look up to her in some ways. Even though we're different, I know she's proud of the life I've built and the values I hold.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Jennifer Bennett: Yes, there are a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Claire, who I met in college through the theater group. She became like a sister to me, and we've stayed close even though she moved to Seattle a few years ago. She's a graphic designer now, and she's always been the one to push me to think creatively and take risks. Then there's Tom, who was my roommate in college and is now a teacher in the Boulder school system. He's been a great friend and mentor to my kids, especially Liam, who really looks up to him. I also have a few friends from the local theater community who I meet up with regularly. We often collaborate on community projects or just get together for coffee and conversation. These friendships have been a big part of my life, and they remind me of the importance of community and support—values that I hold dear and that I try to pass on to my children.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Jennifer Bennett: I live in a neighborhood that feels like a small town within a city. Boulder is known for its natural beauty, and our neighborhood on Aspen Lane is no exception. We're nestled between the foothills of the Rockies and the vibrant downtown area, which makes it the best of both worlds. There are trails just a few blocks away where I like to walk with the kids, and the community here is very tight-knit. Everyone knows each other, and there's always someone to wave at or say hello to when you're out and about. The local park is a favorite spot for families, and there are several community events throughout the year—like the annual fall festival and the summer concert series. I love that there's a strong emphasis on sustainability here, which aligns with my values. We have a lot of bike lanes, community gardens, and even a co-op grocery store that supports local farmers. It's a place where I feel connected to both my family and the people around me, and I'm grateful to call it home.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Jennifer Bennett: I feel very safe here, which is something I really appreciate. There's a sense of community that makes you feel like you're part of something bigger than yourself. I've never had any issues with crime or feeling unsafe, and I think that's partly because of how people look out for each other. If you're walking the trails or just out with the kids, there's always someone nearby who's willing to help if needed. It's also reassuring to know that the city has invested in safety initiatives, like well-lit streets and community policing programs that focus on building trust rather than enforcing fear. I think safety isn't just about the absence of danger—it's about feeling supported and connected, and that's definitely the case here.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Jennifer Bennett: Living here in Boulder has been a mix of blessings and challenges, but overall, I wouldn't trade it for anything. The natural beauty and sense of community are truly remarkable, and I feel like I can breathe here in a way I couldn't in bigger cities. That said, it's not without its difficulties. The cost of living here is high, and while we're doing okay financially, it's something I think about, especially with two kids in school. There's also the pressure of living in a place that's so politically and socially progressive—it can be inspiring, but sometimes it feels like there's an expectation to be perfect in terms of values and actions. I've had to navigate that balance, making sure I stay true to myself while also being part of something larger. Still, the positives far outweigh the negatives. I love that my kids are growing up in a place where they can explore their passions, where people care about each other, and where the environment is protected. It's a place that challenges me to be better, and I think that's a good thing.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood reminded me of how deeply connected I am to the people and place I call home. Talking about my husband, children, and parents brought up so many memories of love, support, and shared values. It also made me reflect on how lucky I am to live in a neighborhood where safety, community, and sustainability are prioritized. It's comforting to know that the values I grew up with—like the importance of education, creativity, and caring for others—are still alive in my family and the people around me. I feel grateful for the life I've built and the sense of belonging I have here in Boulder.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Jennifer Bennett: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it's also flexible enough to accommodate the needs of my family and my own creative pursuits. On weekdays, I usually wake up early, around 6:30 or 7, to get the kids ready for school and have some quiet time before the day gets going. Mark usually takes the kids to school, and I use that time to catch up on reading or planning out any community events I'm involved with. I work part-time at the local community center, helping with literacy programs for kids, which is something I'm really passionate about. After school, the kids come home, and we have a bit of a routine—homework, snacks, and then some time for creative activities. Emily often paints, and Liam is usually tinkering with something related to robotics. In the evenings, we try to have dinner together as a family, and then we might go for a walk or read together. On the weekends, it's a bit more relaxed. We often go hiking in the nearby trails, or we'll attend a local event, like the farmers' market or a community theater performance. I also make time for myself—whether it's writing, attending a workshop, or just enjoying a cup of coffee in the garden. It's a balance, but I think it's one that works for us. I feel lucky to have a life that allows me to be both present for my family and engaged in the things that matter to me.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Jennifer Bennett: I work part-time at the local community center, where I help run literacy programs for kids. It's something I'm really passionate about, and it ties back to my own experiences growing up in a home filled with books. I usually work on weekdays, from 9 a.m. to 12 p.m., which allows me to be present for my kids in the mornings and afternoons. The job is flexible, and I often volunteer for additional events or workshops when I can. It's rewarding to see the kids' faces light up when they discover a love for reading or writing, and it reminds me of the impact that education and creativity can have on someone's life. I also occasionally do some freelance writing for local publications or community newsletters, which gives me a chance to share stories from our neighborhood and highlight the work being done here. It's a small but meaningful way to contribute to the community that has given me so much.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Jennifer Bennett: Yes, there are a few other routines and responsibilities that are important to me. One of them is my weekly participation in a book club that my mother started at the library. It's a small group of women who meet every Thursday evening to discuss literature, and it's become a cherished part of my week. It's not just about reading—it's about connecting with others, sharing perspectives, and keeping the conversation going about the things that matter. I also make it a point to attend at least one local council meeting each month. It's important to me to stay informed about the issues that affect our neighborhood, from environmental policies to education funding. I find that being involved in these ways helps me be a more active and engaged citizen, and it's something I want to model for my children. Finally, I try to set aside time each week for personal reflection—whether it's journaling, meditating, or just sitting in the garden and watching the sunset. It's a way to stay grounded and remind myself of the values that have guided me through life.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Jennifer Bennett: One of the more recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I started doing a short meditation before getting the kids up, and it's made a noticeable difference in how centered I feel throughout the day. It's something I've been inspired to do after attending a workshop at the community center, which was led by a local mindfulness teacher. I also began taking evening walks with my neighbor, Linda, who's a retired yoga instructor. We've started meeting a few times a week to walk the trails and talk about everything from our kids to the latest community news. It's been a nice way to stay connected with someone outside of my immediate family and to keep up with my own well-being. Another change is that I've been experimenting with growing some herbs in our small garden, which has been a fun and rewarding way to spend some quiet time. It's amazing how small changes can add up to make a big difference in your daily life.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Jennifer Bennett: A typical weekday during the school year for my children starts with them getting up around 7:30 a.m., just like me. Emily and Liam have a pretty structured morning—homework, a light breakfast, and then they're off to school. Emily is in middle school, so she has a lot of classes and projects, and she's always juggling different assignments. She's also on the school's art club, which meets after lunch, and she loves that. Liam is in elementary school, and he has a lot of hands-on learning—his favorite part of the day is the robotics club, which meets every Tuesday and Thursday after school. He's always excited to show me what he's built when he comes home. After school, they usually have a snack and then some time to unwind before we have dinner together. On some days, Emily will go to an after-school writing workshop at the community center, and Liam will go to a coding class at the library. I love seeing them engage with their passions, and it's comforting to know that our neighborhood has so many opportunities for kids to explore their interests. It's a balance, but I think it's one that helps them grow both academically and creatively.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how deeply my life is intertwined with the people and values I hold dear. Thinking about my family, my neighborhood, and the routines that shape my days reminded me of how lucky I am to live in a place where community, creativity, and sustainability are not just ideals but lived experiences. It also made me realize how important it is to stay engaged—not just in my family life, but in the broader community around me. Whether it's through my work with the community center, my participation in the book club, or my attendance at local council meetings, I feel like I'm contributing to something bigger than myself. At the same time, these reflections made me appreciate the small, everyday moments that bring meaning to my life, like walking with my neighbor, meditating in the morning, or simply watching the sunset from my garden. It's a reminder that life is not just about the big decisions or the major events, but also about the quiet, consistent choices we make every day to build a life that feels meaningful and connected.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Jennifer Bennett: I've always considered myself to be in pretty good health, though I've had my share of ups and downs over the years. I used to be a bit of a perfectionist about my diet and exercise, but I've learned to be more balanced over time. I do try to eat well—mostly whole foods, plenty of vegetables, and I make sure to include some healthy fats and proteins. I've also been practicing yoga a few times a week, which has helped with both my flexibility and my mental well-being. I used to struggle with stress, especially when I was juggling work, family, and community involvement, but mindfulness and meditation have made a big difference. I also make sure to get enough sleep, even if it's not always easy with two kids and a busy schedule. I've had some minor health issues over the years, like occasional migraines and mild anxiety, but nothing that's ever been too serious. I think the key has been staying active, staying connected with people I care about, and not being too hard on myself when things don't go perfectly. I've learned that health isn't just about the absence of illness—it's about feeling strong, both physically and emotionally, and being able to show up for the people and things that matter most to me.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Jennifer Bennett: For me, what makes it easy to stay healthy is having a strong support system and a lifestyle that naturally incorporates movement and mindfulness. My husband, Mark, is always encouraging me to take walks or try new fitness activities, and our kids often join us when they can. I also find that being part of a community that values wellness—like the yoga classes at the community center or the walking groups that meet at the park—makes it easier to stay consistent. What makes it harder, though, is the constant juggling act of work, family, and personal time. There are days when I feel like I'm running on empty, and it's easy to skip a workout or reach for something quick instead of cooking a healthy meal. I've had to learn to be kind to myself on those days, reminding myself that small choices add up over time. It's not about being perfect—it's about showing up for myself and my family in the best way I can, even on the busiest days.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Jennifer Bennett: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some chronic back pain that started after I helped move some heavy furniture during a community event. At first, I thought it was just a strain, but it didn't go away, and I ended up seeing a chiropractor. They diagnosed me with mild degenerative disc disease, which isn't too serious, but it does require me to be more mindful of how I lift things and sit for long periods. It's been a reminder to take care of my body, especially as I get older. I've started incorporating more stretching into my daily routine and have been using a standing desk at work to give my back a break. It's not perfect, but it's helped me manage the pain better. I also had a minor flare-up during the winter when I was helping organize a local charity drive and spent a lot of time on my feet. That was a tough week, but I learned to listen to my body and take breaks when needed. Overall, it's been a learning experience that has made me more aware of how important it is to prioritize my health, even in small ways.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Jennifer Bennett: Honestly, the back pain has been a challenge, especially when I'm trying to keep up with the kids or work long hours at the community center. There were a few days when I had to sit out on a walk or take a break from helping with an event, which was hard because I don't like to slow down. But I've learned to adapt—sometimes it means asking for help, like having Mark carry the groceries or letting the kids take the lead on a project for a little while. It's also made me more intentional about how I spend my energy. I've started pacing myself more, which has actually helped me be more present for my family and my work. I don't see it as a setback, though—it's just another part of life that reminds me to take care of myself so I can keep showing up for the people and causes I care about.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Jennifer Bennett: Over the past year, I've felt a deep sense of gratitude and contentment, even amidst the challenges that come with life in Boulder. There have been moments of stress, especially with the cost of living and the pressures of keeping up with the kids' schedules, but I've also found a lot of joy in the little things. I've been more intentional about slowing down and really being present—whether it's watching the sunset with my kids, having a meaningful conversation with my husband, or even just sipping coffee in the garden while the birds chirp. I've also felt a renewed sense of purpose in my work at the community center, especially after seeing how the literacy programs have helped some of the kids gain confidence in their reading and writing. It's reminded me why I chose this path in the first place. I think the past year has been a gentle reminder that life is a balance of effort and grace, and I'm learning to embrace both.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my daily routines and health have shaped the way I live and interact with the world. Thinking about the small changes I've made—like incorporating mindfulness into my mornings, walking with my neighbor, and growing herbs in my garden—reminded me of how even the smallest shifts can bring more balance and joy to my life. At the same time, reflecting on my health and the challenges I've faced, like the chronic back pain, made me more aware of how important it is to listen to my body and take care of myself. It's easy to get caught up in the busyness of life, but these moments of reflection have helped me stay grounded and remind me that health is not just about physical well-being—it's also about emotional resilience and the support of the people around me. I'm grateful for the lessons I've learned and the ways I've grown, both in how I take care of myself and how I show up for my family and community.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Jennifer Bennett: I think I've been fortunate in that I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in the way that some people do, but I've had moments where I felt overwhelmed, especially when juggling the demands of work, family, and community involvement. There were times, particularly during the pandemic, when I felt isolated and unsure of how to connect with others in a meaningful way. I remember feeling like I was losing touch with the sense of purpose that had always driven me. But I found my way back through small, consistent acts of connection—whether it was joining the book club, attending local meetings, or simply having deeper conversations with my family. I think it's important to acknowledge when you're feeling off and to reach out for support, even if it's just a friend or a neighbor. I've learned that vulnerability isn't a weakness—it's a way of staying grounded and reminding yourself that you're not alone.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Jennifer Bennett: For my family, the past year has been a mix of growth, challenges, and moments of deep connection. My husband, Mark, has been doing a lot of work in the renewable energy sector, and it's been both exciting and stressful for him. He's been traveling more for projects, which means we've had to adjust to being apart more often than we'd like. But we've made it work—whether through long phone calls, shared meals when he's home, or even video calls during the kids' homework time. Emily and Liam have both been navigating their own changes too. Emily is starting to explore her identity more as a teenager, and while it's been a bit of a rollercoaster, I've been so proud to see her take on leadership roles in her school and art club. Liam, on the other hand, has been really into robotics and has even started entering some local competitions. It's amazing to see his curiosity and determination. As for me, I've been trying to be more present for them, even when life gets busy. I think the past year has taught us all the importance of communication, patience, and finding joy in the everyday moments—whether it's a shared laugh over a silly joke or a quiet evening reading together.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Jennifer Bennett: I think religion and spirituality have always played a quiet but meaningful role in my life. I was raised Protestant, like my mother, but as I grew older, I found myself drawn more to the Catholic faith, which my father practiced. It wasn't a dramatic shift, but more of a gradual realization that the rituals, the sense of community, and the emphasis on compassion and service resonated with me more deeply. I still attend Mass on Sundays, not just as a habit, but because it gives me a sense of grounding. I find that the prayers and the rituals help me stay connected to something larger than myself, especially during times when life feels overwhelming. That said, I don't see my faith as something rigid or exclusive. I believe in the power of love, kindness, and doing good in the world, and I think those values are what truly matter. I also find solace in nature, which I think is a form of spirituality in itself. Walking through the trails here in Boulder, feeling the wind, seeing the sunrise—it all reminds me of the beauty and interconnectedness of life. I don't claim to have all the answers, but I do believe that faith, in whatever form it takes, is a way of staying open to the world and to the people in it.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Jennifer Bennett: I actually don't use social media very often, and when I do, it's more for staying in touch with family and friends rather than for scrolling through news or trends. I have a Facebook account where I keep up with my parents, my sister, and some of my old college friends. I also follow a few local community pages that share updates about events, volunteer opportunities, and environmental initiatives—those are the kinds of things that matter to me. I used to be more active on Instagram, but I found that it started to feel more like a comparison game than a way to connect. I prefer the slower, more intentional way of communicating, like through letters or in-person conversations. I think it's important to be present in the moment, and I've found that limiting my time online helps me do that. Plus, with two kids who are always on their devices, I want to model a different kind of behavior for them—one that values real connection over digital validation.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Jennifer Bennett: Honestly, I haven't found myself turning to social media for support during tough times, though I can see how it might help others. For me, support has always come from the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, and the community here in Boulder. When things have been difficult, like when I was dealing with the back pain or feeling overwhelmed with work and family, it was my husband who reminded me to take it slow, or my mother who sent me a thoughtful letter or called just to check in. I think there's something powerful about the kind of support that comes from genuine connection, rather than online interactions that can sometimes feel superficial. That said, I do appreciate the way social media can bring awareness to important issues, and I've followed a few local activists or environmental groups who share meaningful content. But for personal support, I've always leaned on the people I know and love in person.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how my health and emotional well-being are deeply intertwined with the support of the people around me. Thinking about the chronic back pain I've been dealing with reminded me of how important it is to listen to my body and take care of myself, even when life gets busy. It also made me appreciate the ways in which my family and friends have helped me through difficult times, whether it was my husband reminding me to slow down or my mother checking in with a thoughtful letter. Reflecting on my mental health, I realized that while I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in the way some people do, I've still had moments of feeling overwhelmed, especially during the pandemic. Those experiences taught me the value of small, consistent acts of connection—like joining the book club or having meaningful conversations with my family. It's a reminder that vulnerability isn't a weakness, but a way of staying grounded and remembering that I'm not alone. Overall, these reflections have deepened my understanding of how health—both physical and emotional—is not just about individual effort, but also about the support and love of the people who walk beside me.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Jennifer Bennett: In the past year, I've found that my stress levels have actually decreased, which is something I didn't expect. I think it's because I've been more intentional about how I spend my time and energy. I've started setting clearer boundaries between work, family, and personal time, which has helped me feel more in control. I also make it a point to pause and reflect each evening, whether it's through journaling or just sitting quietly in the garden. These small practices have helped me process my emotions more effectively and stay grounded. I've also leaned more on my support system—whether it's talking to my husband, joining the book club, or simply having a cup of tea with my neighbor. I've learned that it's okay to not have all the answers, and that emotional resilience comes from being present, asking for help when needed, and finding joy in the little moments that remind me why I'm here.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Jennifer Bennett: Last month, our biggest expenses were related to the kids' school supplies and extracurricular activities. Emily is in middle school now, and the cost of art materials, plus her after-school writing workshops, added up. Liam's robotics classes and competition fees also took a chunk out of our budget. Then there's the monthly rent for our home on Aspen Lane—Boulder's housing market is tough, and while we're doing okay, it's always something we keep an eye on. Groceries are another big one, especially since we try to eat healthy and support local farmers through the co-op store. We also have a few bills related to our car, insurance, and utilities. To make ends meet, I work part-time at the community center, and Mark's job in renewable energy is steady, though it does require some travel. We also rely on a small savings account and occasionally take on small freelance writing projects to cover unexpected costs. It's not always easy, but we've learned to be resourceful and prioritize what matters most—like our family, our health, and our community.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Jennifer Bennett: Last month, our household spent around $4,500, which is actually a bit higher than usual. The increase was mostly due to Emily's new art supplies and the cost of her after-school writing workshop, which she's really passionate about. Liam's robotics competition fees also added up, and we had a few unexpected expenses, like a new set of tires for the car. On a typical month, we usually spend between $3,800 and $4,200. The biggest regular expenses are rent, groceries, and the kids' school-related costs. We also set aside money for utilities, insurance, and a small amount for savings. It's not always easy to balance everything, but we've found that prioritizing what matters most—like our family and our community—helps us stay grounded, even when the numbers get tight.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Jennifer Bennett: We rent our home on Aspen Lane. It's a cozy two-story house with a small garden, and we've been living here for about six years now. Renting has been the practical choice for us, especially with the way the housing market is in Boulder. While we'd love to own a home someday, the prices here are just too high for us to afford with our current income. Mark and I have been careful with our budget, and we're lucky that both of our jobs provide some stability. We've also been fortunate to have a few family members who have helped us out with unexpected expenses over the years, which has made a big difference. Renting allows us the flexibility to be near the community center where I work and close to the schools for the kids, which is something we really value. It's not perfect, but it's a choice that fits our lifestyle and priorities right now.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Jennifer Bennett: Over the past year, our bills have definitely fluctuated based on the seasons and events. In the winter, for example, our heating costs went up, and we had to budget more for utilities. We also spent more on groceries during the holidays, especially when we hosted a few family gatherings. On the flip side, summer brought some unexpected savings—like when we used our garden more for fresh herbs and vegetables, which cut down on grocery costs a bit. School-related expenses also vary; in the fall, we had to budget for back-to-school supplies, uniforms, and extracurricular fees, while in the spring, we spent more on field trips and special events. There were also a few months when we had to set aside extra money for car maintenance or unexpected repairs, which can be tough when you're already stretching your budget. But overall, we've learned to be flexible and plan ahead as much as possible, knowing that some costs are seasonal and others are just part of the rhythm of life with two kids in school.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my family and community support have shaped my emotional well-being and resilience. Thinking about how my husband, Mark, has adjusted to his work schedule and how we've maintained our connection despite being apart more often reminded me of the strength of our relationship. It also made me appreciate how my children, Emily and Liam, are growing into their own identities and finding their passions, which brings me so much joy and pride. At the same time, reflecting on my health struggles, like the chronic back pain, reminded me of how important it is to listen to my body and take care of myself, even when life gets busy. It also made me think about how I've leaned on my family and friends for support during tough times, rather than turning to social media, and how that kind of real, heartfelt connection is something I value deeply. These reflections have reinforced my belief that true support comes from the people we know and love in person, and that our emotional resilience is built on those relationships, not on digital interactions or comparisons.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Jennifer Bennett: I do have a savings account, though it's not huge—it's more of a buffer for unexpected expenses rather than a long-term investment. We try to set aside a small portion of our income each month, usually around $200 to $300, depending on how the rest of the budget looks. It's not always easy, especially with the way our expenses can fluctuate, but it gives us some peace of mind knowing we have a little something saved for emergencies. I also have a separate jar at home where I keep cash for smaller, everyday purchases—like groceries or gas—so I don't get caught off guard by the little things. I think saving, even in small ways, is about being responsible and thoughtful with what we have. It's not about being rich, but about being prepared and making choices that align with our values—like supporting our kids' passions, staying in our community, and keeping our home here in Boulder. It's a way of saying, 'We're in this together,' and I think that's something worth saving for.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Jennifer Bennett: In the last year, I've been saving more with the intention of creating a rainy day fund, rather than aiming for a big purchase like a home. It's not that we don't dream about owning a house someday, but with the current market, it feels more realistic to focus on building a financial cushion. I think it's important to have that safety net, especially with two kids in school and the unpredictable nature of life. I've also started setting aside a little extra each month for things like Emily's art supplies or Liam's robotics competitions, knowing that these are passions they're really invested in. It's not about saving for luxury—it's about supporting the things that matter most to our family and making sure we can continue to live in a way that aligns with our values. I've learned that saving doesn't have to be about big goals; sometimes, it's about small, consistent choices that add up over time and give you the freedom to say yes to the things that bring joy and meaning to your life.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Jennifer Bennett: I've always considered myself to be someone who finds purpose in supporting others, whether through education, community work, or simply being there for the people I love. My occupation, in many ways, is a reflection of that. I work part-time at the local community center, where I help run literacy programs for kids. It's not just about teaching them to read—it's about helping them find confidence in their voices, just like I did when I was their age. I spend a lot of time planning activities, organizing workshops, and working one-on-one with children who need extra support. I also collaborate with teachers and parents to make sure we're all on the same page about each child's progress. The most important part of my job, though, is seeing the light in their eyes when they finally understand something new or when they share a story they've written. It reminds me why I chose this path in the first place—to make a difference, even in small ways, and to help others find the same sense of purpose that has guided me through life.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Jennifer Bennett: I usually work around 15 to 20 hours a week at the community center, depending on the season and the number of events we're running. During the school year, I tend to work more hours because the literacy programs are in full swing, and there are more workshops and activities for the kids. In the summer, I sometimes reduce my hours a bit, but I still stay involved with planning and volunteering for community events. It's a flexible schedule, which is something I really appreciate because it allows me to be present for my kids and still contribute to the things I care about. I also do some freelance writing on the side, which gives me a bit more freedom in terms of when I work. It's not a huge income, but it's enough to help support our family and give me a sense of purpose beyond just being a mother and a wife. I think the key is finding a balance that works for us, and I'm grateful that I can do something I love while still being there for my family.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Jennifer Bennett: Yes, I do have a few other sources of income and responsibilities outside of my work at the community center. In addition to my part-time job, I occasionally take on freelance writing projects for local publications and community newsletters, which I mentioned before. It's not a regular job, but it gives me a chance to share stories from our neighborhood and highlight the work being done here. I also volunteer with the local theater group, helping with set design and event planning when I can. It's something I'm passionate about, and it keeps me connected to the creative community that was so important in shaping who I am. On weekends, I sometimes take on small home organizing or decluttering projects for neighbors, which is a way to earn a little extra money while also staying active. It's not always easy juggling all of these things, but I find that having a variety of responsibilities keeps me engaged and gives me a sense of purpose beyond just one role. I think it's important to stay busy in ways that align with your values, and for me, that means supporting my family, contributing to the community, and staying connected to the things I love.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how my emotional well-being and financial stability are deeply connected to the support systems I have in place. Thinking about how my stress levels have decreased over the past year reminded me of the importance of setting boundaries and being intentional with my time and energy. It also made me appreciate the small, consistent practices I've adopted—like journaling, reflecting each evening, and leaning on my support system—to help me stay grounded and process my emotions more effectively. At the same time, reflecting on our household budget and the challenges of making ends meet reminded me of how resourceful and resilient we've become as a family. It's not always easy, but knowing that we can rely on each other, our community, and our values helps us navigate the ups and downs of life with more grace and purpose. I'm grateful for the balance we've found and the ways in which we continue to grow, both emotionally and financially, as a family.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Jennifer Bennett: In total, our household made around $5,200 in the past month. That includes my part-time income from the community center, Mark's salary from his work in renewable energy, and the small amount I earn from freelance writing. It's not a huge sum, but it's enough to cover our basic needs and support the things that matter most to us—like our kids' passions, our community involvement, and keeping our home here in Boulder. I've learned that it's not about how much money we make, but how we choose to use it. We prioritize experiences over things, and we try to live in a way that aligns with our values. It's not always easy, but I feel grateful for the life we've built and the way we're able to support each other and the people around us.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Jennifer Bennett: I've been working at the community center for about five years now, and it's become such a meaningful part of my life. The benefits of the job are pretty standard—health insurance, a few days of paid time off each year, and some sick days. While it's not a full-time position, the flexibility is something I really value. I can adjust my schedule to be there for my kids when they need me, and I still feel like I'm making a difference in the lives of the children who come through the literacy programs. The best part, though, is the sense of community that comes with the job. I work with amazing people who are all passionate about education and supporting kids, and it's inspiring to be part of that. I also appreciate that the center offers some professional development opportunities, like workshops on teaching strategies or creative writing, which helps me grow as an educator and as a person. It's not just a job—it's a way to stay connected to the values that have always guided me, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Jennifer Bennett: My relationships at work are very positive and supportive. I have a great relationship with my manager, Sarah, who has been a mentor to me since I started. She's always encouraged me to take on new challenges and has given me the freedom to be creative with the literacy programs. She's not just a boss—she's like a friend who genuinely cares about the people she works with. As for my coworkers, we have a strong sense of camaraderie. We all share a passion for education and making a difference in the lives of the kids we work with. We often collaborate on ideas, support each other during busy times, and even have lunch breaks together when we can. It's a workplace that feels like a second family, and I'm really grateful for that. I think the shared values of community, creativity, and compassion make our relationships at work not just professional, but deeply personal.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Jennifer Bennett: My work schedule is pretty flexible, which is one of the things I love most about my job. I usually work Monday through Friday, but my hours can shift depending on the needs of the community center and the kids in the literacy programs. Some weeks I might start a little later if I have a meeting in the morning or need to adjust for a school event, and other weeks I might stay a bit later to wrap up a workshop or help a child who needs extra support. The flexibility allows me to be present for my family while still contributing to the community. It's not always perfect—there are times when I have to adjust my plans last minute or work on weekends for special events—but overall, I feel like I have a good balance. It's a schedule that works for me, and I'm grateful for the understanding and support I've received from my manager and coworkers.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Jennifer Bennett: Overall, I feel pretty content with our financial situation, even though it's not without its challenges. We're not wealthy, but we're not struggling either. I think the key for us has always been prioritizing what truly matters—our family, our health, and our community. We've learned to live within our means, and while it sometimes means making tough choices, like skipping a vacation or limiting our spending on non-essentials, I don't regret it. What I do feel proud of is the fact that we're able to support our kids' passions and give them opportunities to grow and explore their interests. I also feel grateful that we're in a place where we can afford to live in Boulder, even if it's through renting, and that we can contribute to the community in meaningful ways. I know that financial stability isn't the only measure of a good life, and I think we've found a balance that allows us to live with purpose, connection, and a sense of gratitude.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Jennifer Bennett: Yes, both my parents worked while I was growing up, though their roles were quite different. My father was a professor of environmental science, and he worked full-time at the university for many years. He was always very dedicated to his work, but he also made sure to be present for our family. He would come home every evening, even if it was late, and we'd have dinner together. My mother, on the other hand, didn't work outside the home for most of my childhood. She had a bachelor's degree and had been a teacher before she chose to stay home with us. She was always very involved in our lives, reading to us, helping with our school projects, and encouraging our creative interests. Looking back, I think that balance between my father's career and my mother's role as a homemaker gave me a strong foundation. It showed me the value of education, the importance of family, and the power of support—things that have shaped who I am today.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Jennifer Bennett: My father's job was as a professor of environmental science at a university in our mountain town. His most important activities involved teaching, conducting research on sustainable practices, and mentoring students who were passionate about the environment. He was always very dedicated to his work, but he also made sure to be present for our family. He would come home every evening, even if it was late, and we'd have dinner together. He had a way of making complex topics feel accessible, and I remember him explaining things like climate change or renewable energy in ways that made me curious about the world. My mother, on the other hand, didn't work outside the home for most of my childhood. She had a bachelor's degree and had been a teacher before she chose to stay home with us. She was always very involved in our lives—reading to us, helping with our school projects, and encouraging our creative interests. Looking back, I think that balance between my father's career and my mother's role as a homemaker gave me a strong foundation. It showed me the value of education, the importance of family, and the power of support—things that have shaped who I am today.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Jennifer Bennett: My father worked for a public university in our mountain town, which was a place that valued education, research, and community engagement. The university was a hub for environmental studies, and my father was part of a department that focused on sustainable practices and conservation. His work involved teaching undergraduate and graduate students, leading research projects on renewable energy and land preservation, and collaborating with local communities to find solutions to environmental challenges. He was very hands-on, often taking students on field trips to study ecosystems or helping them design projects that had real-world impact. As for what he made, I don't remember the exact figures, but I know he earned a good salary for a professor, and it was enough to provide for our family comfortably. What I remember most is how passionate he was about his work and how he always found ways to connect it back to our lives at home. He would bring home articles or books about environmental issues, and we'd discuss them over dinner. It was through him that I first became aware of the importance of taking care of the planet and using knowledge to make a difference.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Jennifer Bennett: Looking a few years ahead, I hope to continue living in Boulder, surrounded by the people and values that have shaped my life. I hope my children, Emily and Liam, are still pursuing their passions—whether that's art, writing, or robotics—and that they grow up to be compassionate, curious, and engaged members of their community. I also hope to continue working at the community center, maybe even expanding the literacy programs to reach more kids, especially those who might not have the same opportunities I had. I'd love to see our neighborhood remain a place where sustainability, creativity, and connection are at the heart of everyday life. On a personal level, I hope to continue taking care of my health, maybe even exploring more of the trails and natural beauty that have always brought me peace. I also hope to keep writing, whether it's stories for the community newsletter or something more personal. I think the future is less about where I end up and more about the kind of life I continue to build—one that values family, community, and the quiet, meaningful moments that make life worth living.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Jennifer Bennett: What I value the most in my life is the sense of connection—whether it's with my family, my friends, or the community I live in. I believe that we're all part of something bigger, and that our lives are shaped by the relationships we build and the values we hold. I value education because it's the foundation of opportunity and understanding, and I value creativity because it allows us to express ourselves and see the world in new ways. I also value compassion—both for myself and for others. Life can be challenging, and I think it's important to be kind to yourself when things don't go as planned, and to extend that same kindness to others. I value the natural world, too, because it reminds me of the beauty and interconnectedness of life. And finally, I value the small, everyday moments—the laughter with my kids, the quiet time in the garden, the conversations over coffee with friends. These are the things that make life meaningful, and I'm grateful for them every day.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a deeply reflective journey for me. It reminded me of how much my life has been shaped by the people, experiences, and values I've held close. From my childhood in Colorado, surrounded by books and music, to the pivotal moment in college when I discovered my passion for storytelling through theater, each chapter of my life has led me to where I am today. I've come to realize that the choices I've made—whether it was pursuing a career in education, leaning into my creativity, or choosing to live in a community that values sustainability and connection—have all been guided by a deep belief in the power of stories, education, and compassion. This reflection has also made me appreciate the support I've received from my family, friends, and community, and how their influence has helped me grow into the person I am now. I feel grateful for the life I've built, and I'm reminded that even the smallest decisions can have a lasting impact on who we become and the lives we touch.
